We add up the three equations together as follows:
$(x_1-x_2)^2 + (y_1-y_2)^2 + (x_1-x_3)^2 + (y_1-y_3)^2 + (x_2-x_3)^2 + (y_2-y_3)^2=9+16+25=50$. Now recall Vieta's formulas relating sums/products of roots vs coefficients; using them here yields $|S| = |V|$ where S denotes vector formed by differences among variables ($\vec{a}= (\ldots,\ldots)$ etc.). Thus $|\vec{Q}|^{2}$ equals determinant matrix squared value computed via standard cofactor expansion method along first row -- yielding ${}^{2}\left|\begin{array}{ccc} x_{1} & y_{1} & 1 \\ x_{2} & y_{2} & 1 \\ x_{3} & y_{3} & 1 \end{array}\right|^{2}$, thus giving us our desired solution!

We start by expanding the determinant using Laplace expansion along the first row: \[
\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}=x_1\begin{vmatrix} y_2 & 1 \\ y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}-y_1\begin{vmatrix} x_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}+1\begin{vmatrix} x_2 & y_2 \\ x_3 & y_3 \end{vmatrix}.
\] Now let us substitute each term one by one into our expressions above:\[ \begin{aligned} (x_1 - x_2)^2 + (y_1 - y_2)^2&=x_1^2-2x_1x_2+x_2^2+y_1^2-2y_1y_2+y_2^2=9,\\ (x_1 - x_3)^2 + (y_1 - y_3)^2&

1.subquestion: Add up the three equations above.

subanswer.text: Adding them together yields \[\begin{aligned}(x_{1}- x_{2})^{2}+(y_{1}- y_{2})^{2}&+\\{}&=(x_{1}- x_{3})^{2}+(y_{1}- y_{3})^{2}&+\\{}&+(x_{2}- x_{3})^{2}+(y_{2}- y_{3})^{2}\\&=(\text {sum}\;of\;squares)\end{aligned}\] This simplifies to $30=a^2+b^2+c^2,\quad where\quad a=-x_1+x_2+x_3,$ etc., so $|a|<30.$ Therefore, using Cauchy's inequality or Lagrange identity,we know that $$\begin{vmatrix} x_{1}&y_{1}&1 \\ x_{2}&y_{2}&1 \\ x_{3}&y_{3}&1 \end{vmatrix}^{2}$$ lies within $[0,(abc)^{2}/30].$$ Thus, our final possible range cannot exceed $(\pm (\tfrac{ab}{30})^{2})^{\tfrac{3}{2}}.$ Answer $$D:\;\;[\tfrac{(a)(bc)}{30},\infty)$$ Next, observe that if any side length were zero,then at least two would have been equal, making their sum less than halfway across perimeter$\Rightarrow \;d<\tfrac{1}{2}(\;|\vec p|$),where $\vec p$ denotes the triangle’s perimeter.Then use Pythagoras theorem ($r=\tfrac{p}{2}$):$$ r^2 =\biggl(\tfrac{1}{2}|\;\vec p |\biggr)^{\!2}+\bigl((ac)/30\bigr)^{\!2},\,\quad 9+\bigl((ac)/30\bigr)^{\!2}>\biggl(\tfrac{1}{2}|\;\vec p |\biggr)^{\!2}$$ which means $|\;\vec p\,|$ must lie outside circle centred at origin with radius $\bigl(\tfrac{1}{2}|\;\vec p |\bigr)$. Using scalar triple product formulae shows that its magnitude ranges over interval $[-(abc)/30,\; ab/30],$ hence**Final Range:[$(abc)/30,\;(abc)/30]$

2.subquestion: Calculate the determinant directly as follows:

subanswer.text: Expanding along rows or columns, either row OR column containing largest terms leads here quickly:After some rearrangement,this becomes simply squaring off something like below.$$\Bigg(-\frac{ab}{(abc)}cos\theta\Bigg)^2 +\Bigg(\frac{cd}{(abc)}\sin\theta\Bigg)^2+\Bigg(\frac{ac}{(abc)}\times\frac{bd}{(abc)}\Bigg)^2\\=\underbrace{\frac{1}{a^2+b^2}}_{\triangle AOB}\,OC^{2} +\overbrace{\frac{1}{c^2+d^2}}^{area \,BPQC}\,PC^{2} + \underbrace{\frac{1}{a^2+d^2}}_{OCD,\, area\, CDO}\,OD^{2},$$which matches previous derivation since angles opposite those lengths are right angled.. Answer **Range: [$(abc)/30,\;(abc)/30]$. Final Result:[$[(abc)/30,\;(abc)/30]$ ] Question 6: In how many different orders may six runners finish a race if no ties are allowed? I think everything should just multiply according to permutations but somehow my book says ${}_6P_6$ instead... Is this wrong too??? And anyway don't they say you need more info before calculating probabilities?? Or does having every runner finishing differently imply information about time distribution among winners.... Anyway back to orderings now--since positions only matter not who actually wins last vs third place ect, let n=$x_i > x_j , i< j$; define f($n$) giving total unique possibilities starting with sequence $n$:$$I:$A:$=\{$unique arrangements $\{x\}$ s.t \$ \{x\}⊆\{x∈ℤ₊│∃x₁,...,x₆∀1≤k≤6(|xᵢ＞xᵢ₋₁∧xₖ≠xₖ₋₁)|}\$} .$$ Then $F(n)=\displaystyle\sum_{\forall M\subseteq N\setminus\{n\}}\binom{N}{\vertM\vert}\cdot F(M)$ with base case being empty set size${}_6P_6$.So why am I told things might go better with binomial coeffients?:*For example take smallest integer winning

1.subquestion: What does squaring the determinant look like written as elements in matrix form?

subanswer.text: Squaring the determinant means computing \[\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = (\det \mathbf{A})^2,\]where $$\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$$ The answer is $(\det \mathbf{A})^2$.

1.subquestion: What does squaring the determinant look like written as elements in matrix form?

subanswer.text: Squaring the determinant means computing \[\begin{vmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{vmatrix}^2 = (\det \mathbf{A})^2,\]where $$\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} x_1 & y_1 & 1 \\ x_2 & y_2 & 1 \\ x_3 & y_3 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$$ The answer is $(\det \mathbf{A})^2$.

direct_answer.text:

    x_{1}-x_{3}&y_{1}-y_{3}&1 \\

      x_{3}&y_{3}&1
   \end{array}\right|)^{2}$$Next expand out using Laplace expansion along first column; last term vanishes due symmetry about middle vertical line since entries above diagonal equal those below minus sign flips same way.$$[\left( (x_{1}-x_{3})(y_{2}-y_{3})-(y_{1}-y_{3})(x_{2}-x_{3})) -(x_{2}-x_{3})(y_{1}-y_{3})\right])^{2}=[(xy'-yx')-(xy'-yx'))^{2}\\=(2xy'-2yx
